summary_points: 1. Dollar Tree sold its Family Dollar business for $1,007 million, expecting net proceeds of approximately $800 million by the end of the second quarter of fiscal 2025.
2. As of June 4, 2025, Dollar Tree has a $2 million shortfall in letter of credit funds allocated to its supply chain financing program.

3. The $800 million in net proceeds from the Family Dollar sale will be used to reduce supply chain financing program obligations, with the remaining $798 million allocated for general corporate purposes.

1. Old Dominion Freight Line, Inc. reported a 5.8% decrease in revenue per day in May 2025 compared to May 2024, due to lower LTL tons per day, partially offset by increased revenue per hundredweight.
2. Quarter-to-date (as of June 4th, 2025) LTL revenue per hundredweight increased 3.2% year-over-year, while LTL revenue per hundredweight excluding fuel surcharges increased 5.6%.

3.  The company cites continued softness in the domestic economy and lower fuel prices as impacting their May 2025 revenue, while expressing uncertainty about the macroeconomic environment and listing numerous risks in their SEC filing.
1. On June 2, 2025, Andrew Witty's performance-based restricted stock units were cancelled in connection with his retirement from his position as Chief Executive Officer.
2.  At the 2025 Annual Meeting, the shareholder proposal regarding excessive golden parachutes was rejected by a vote of 94,676,898 for and 655,943,208 against.
3.  The 2025 Annual Meeting saw 811,952,044 shares of common stock represented, with various resolutions regarding director elections and executive compensation receiving votes.
1. Dollar Tree sold its Family Dollar business for approximately $1,007 million, expecting net proceeds of $800 million and tax benefits of $350 million, with the sale closing by August 2025.
2.  First-quarter 2025 (ended May 3, 2025) net sales increased by 11.3% to $4.6 billion, driven by higher traffic and average ticket.

3. Dollar Tree anticipates a significant 45-50% year-over-year decrease in adjusted diluted earnings per share for the second quarter of 2025, before a projected recovery in the latter half of the year to reach a full-year target of $5.15 to $5.65 per share.
1.  As of April 30, 2025, four end-users represented 10% or more of the company's financing receivables, totaling 74% of all financing receivables.

2.  The company anticipates $19 million to $26 million in cash expenditures for severance payments and related costs, and $10 million to $20 million in non-cash charges for stock-based compensation, as part of a new strategic plan announced on May 6, 2025.

3. The company is facing several lawsuits related to a July 19, 2024, system crash, including a securities class action lawsuit and consolidated class action lawsuits related to airline flight disruptions,  with unspecified monetary damages sought in each.

1. Gartner Inc.'s 2025 Annual Meeting of Stockholders was held on May 29, 2025, resulting in the election of eleven nominees to the board of directors,  advisory approval of named executive officer compensation, and ratification of KPMG LLP as the independent auditor.
2.  While all board nominees were elected,  support ranged from 56,293,754 votes for William O. Grabe to 66,171,330 votes for Eileen M. Serra, indicating varying levels of shareholder support.
3. No future impacts or risks were explicitly stated in this 8-K filing.

1. Arista Networks, Inc.'s 2025 Annual Meeting on May 30, 2025, resulted in the election of three Class II directors, an advisory approval of named executive officer compensation, and ratification of Ernst & Young LLP as the independent auditor for the fiscal year ending December 31, 2025.
2.  Charles Giancarlo received 656,128,725 "For" votes, Daniel Scheinman received 675,755,003 "For" votes, and Yvonne Wassenaar received 744,203,569 "For" votes in the director elections.
3. The advisory vote on named executive officer compensation resulted in 613,624,231 "For" votes and 374,475,398 "Against" votes.
